bibl.title: Letter from T.H.D. Griffitts to Henry Rose Carter, January 22, 1922

div1.p: Griffitts believes that Carter's abstracts are of great value. He may move to Mobile, Alabama for a malaria project.

div1.head: Letter from T.H.D. Griffitts to Henry Rose Carter, January 22, 1922

Mal,
Abstract
(Stegomia in Ill
MOBILE, ALABAMA
Jan. 22, 1922.
Dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
Your letter relative to malaria
Abstracts was forwarded to me
here.

1. Abstracts are of some value to one
interested in the subject matter when
the “abstractor” merely has editorial
ability, but with not even general
knowledge of the subject.

2. They have more value than (1)
when the “abstractor” has a general
knowledge of the subject matter.

3. They have decidedly increased
value when the “abstractor” is
an authority or expert in the
subject matter

4. Abstracts by one who is thoroughly
familiar with the subject and
who “interprets”, as you do in your
malaria abstracts, have the greatest
possible value.

FIRE PROOF
THE CAWTHON
JEN DOUBLIE RAYS JAMAIS
2
P. C. STEELE, MGR.
MOBILE, ALABAMA

By all means, I should say,
that you will accomplish the
greatest amount of good by
continuing as you are doing.
Most of the abstracts are of foreign
literature -- not so much need for
abs. of work in States -- and
all of us now, and most of us
in the future, need care for
information regarding malaria ex-
cept as it may be applied in
our own conditions and their
connection. You are making
the knowledge available, as
it can in no other way be
made.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, H D Griffitts c/o City Health Officer
Mobile, Ala.

div1.p:
I have been here for several
days assisting Dr. Mohr in getting
affairs shaped up for malaria
control. There is little doubt but
that the County and City Com-
missioners will make $35,000, tomorrow
night.

I presume I will have to pull
up and move here. The Bureau
did not give me what I asked. If
I were an “ex-soldier” it would
be different. It's like “Ireland for
the Irish”, I guess.

I don't know when I'll see the
family. I'll just apply a little Chinese
philosophy

“Your arm is broken? Do not grieve
Aloud, but hide it in your sleeve.”
